edge: Blade Runner 2049 is a sequel to Blade Runner, directed by Denis Villeneuve.
K is played by Ryan Gosling in Blade Runner 2049.
Harrison Ford reprises his role as Rick Deckard from the previous film, Blade Runner.
Joi is played by Ana de Armas in Blade Runner 2049.
Sylvia Hoeks plays a replicant in Blade Runner 2049.
Robin Wright reprises her role as Luther from the previous film, Blade Runner.
Mackenzie Davis plays Mariette in Blade Runner 2049.
Dave Bautista plays Sapper Morton in Blade Runner 2049.
Jared Leto plays Neander Wallace in Blade Runner 2049.
Blade Runner, directed by Ridley Scott, was released in 1982.
Blade Runner 2049 is set in the year 2049.
Blade Runner 2049 premiered and was released in Los Angeles, California.
Bioengineered humans known as replicants are still used for slave labor in the year 2049, as depicted in Blade Runner 2049.
KD6-3.7 is a Nexus-9 replicant who works as a blade runner in Blade Runner 2049.
In Blade Runner 2049, K (short for serial number, KD6-3.7), a Nexus-9 replicant, works as a blade runner for the Los Angeles Police Department.
Blade Runner 2049 received acclaim from critics in October 2017.

node_1: biggest box-office bombs of the year
edge: Despite receiving acclaim, Blade Runner 2049 was one of the biggest box-office bombs of the year.
Blade Runner 2049 had a production budget of $150–185 million.
Blade Runner 2049 failed to reach its estimated break-even point of $400 million.
Blade Runner 2049 received Academy Awards for Best Cinematography and Best Visual Effects in 2018.
A sequel television series, Blade Runner 2099, is in development at Amazon Studios with Ridley Scott set to return as executive producer.

Sapper Morton retired and K found a box buried under a tree at Morton's farm, which contained the remains of a female replicant who died during a caesarean section. This discovery raised questions about the biological reproduction capabilities of replicants.
K's superior, Lt. Joshi, fears that the knowledge of replicant reproduction could lead to war between humans and replicants, prompting her to order K to retire the replicant child.
DNA archives identified the deceased female found by K as Rachael, an experimental Nexus 7 replicant.
Rachael had romantic ties with former blade runner Rick Deckard, as revealed during K's investigation.
The Wallace Corporation succeeded the defunct Tyrell Corporation in the manufacture of replicants.
CEO Niander Wallace sends his replicant enforcer, Luv, to monitor K in his investigation.
Niander Wallace wants the secret to replicant reproduction to expand interstellar colonization.
K recognizes the date from a childhood memory of a wooden toy horse and believes it is evidence that he was born, not created.
K's holographic A.I. girlfriend Joi believes the evidence found at Morton's farm is proof that K was born.

node_2: two children born on 6.10.21 with identical dna aside from the sex chromosome
edge: K discovers in LAPD records two children born on that date with identical DNA aside from the sex chromosome, but only the boy is listed as alive.
K recognizes the orphanage and finds the toy horse in the furnace where he remembers hiding it.
Replicant memory designer Dr. Ana Stelline confirms that K's memory of the orphanage is authentic, leading K to conclude he is Rachael's son.
K fails a baseline test, marking him as rogue.
When K implies to Joshi that he killed the replicant child, she gives him 48 hours to pass the test, or he will be 'retired'.
hires replicant prostitute Mariette as a surrogate for her to have sex with K. The following morning, Mariette places a tracker on K’s jacket prior to being sent away by a jealous Joi.

urges K to kill Deckard as he may give up Stelline or the replicant freedom movement to Wallace

node_1: licensing disputes over philip k. dick's novel do androids dream of electric sheep?
edge: Licensing disputes over Philip K. Dick's 1968 novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? had deterred the creation of sequels to the science fiction drama Blade Runner (1982).
Director Ridley Scott conceived two ultimately unrealized projects vaguely connected to the Blade Runner canon in the interim, such as a stand-alone sequel titled Metropolis.
Scott's second project, a collaboration with his son Luke and younger brother Tony titled Purefold, had been imagined as an episodic webseries examining conceptions of empathy.

Alcon Entertainment co-founders Andrew Kosove and Broderick Johnson purchased the intellectual property from producer Bud Yorkin, which entitled them rights to syndication, franchising, and derivative media such as prequels and sequels, excluding a remake of the original Blade Runner film.
Alcon Entertainment named Christopher Nolan one of their ideal choices to direct, but Nolan said he never planned to direct despite being an admirer of the Blade Runner franchise.
The terms of Alcon's acquisition prohibited a remake but entitled them rights to produce sequels and prequels.
Kosove and Johnson sought to increase Alcon's output of blockbuster films due to investor funding scarce and unsatisfied with the profits from their smaller-budget features.
Alcon Entertainment co-founders Andrew Kosove and Broderick Johnson purchased the intellectual property from producer Bud Yorkin for syndication, franchising, and derivative media.

Blade Runner was a source of inspiration for Villeneuve's passion for filmmaking. Villeneuve hesitated to accept the assignment for Blade Runner 2049 due to fears of tarnishing the franchise's legacy, but ultimately accepted because he liked the screenplay and was assured by Fancher's investment in the project.

Alcon producers refused to grant copyright approval for a scene from Ready Player One set in the Blade Runner universe, as they feared it would affect their commercial prospects, despite the fact that Ready Player One was released months later.
Villeneuve and Alcon producers had an existing professional relationship from Prisoners (2013). Villeneuve met with Alcon producers for negotiations at a cafe in rural New Mexico.

The filmmakers embarked on location scouting in April 2016 for Blade Runner 2049.
Principal photography of Blade Runner 2049 commenced in July and lasted for four months until November.
The filmmakers toured London for location scouting but found no soundstage available for the needs of the production.
As a result, Deakins and Villeneuve flew to Hungary for location scouting partly due to Scott's familiarity with the country's network of facilities.
They also toured Slovakia to source architectural ideas.
Shooting took place mainly at Korda Studios and the Origo Studios backlot in suburban Budapest.
Shooting took place mainly at Korda Studios and the Origo Studios backlot in suburban Budapest.
Shooting took place mainly at Korda Studios and the Origo Studios backlot in suburban Budapest.
The production crew were mostly Hungarian, with some American staff hired to supervise the set in Hungary.
$180 million ($90 million each) was allocated by the Alcon-Sony partnership for the Blade Runner 2049 budget, with rebates notwithstanding.
Doubled for Las Vegas in casino-set scenes from Blade Runner 2049 due to filming locations in Budapest.

node_1: budapest stock exchange's liberty square palace
edge: In Blade Runner 2049, the Budapest Stock Exchange's Liberty Square palace doubled for Las Vegas in casino-set scenes due to filming locations.
The abandoned Inota and Kelenföld power plants emphasized Blade Runner 2049's dystopian ethos during filming.
In Blade Runner 2049, the filmmakers revised Deckard's capture by Luv into a simple conversational scene after Ford conveyed his disapproval of the dialogue.

node_2: new york city press junket for la la land (2016)
edge: Gosling's obligation to fulfill a New York City press junket for La La Land (2016) exacerbated the unusual circumstances of Blade Runner 2049 shoot, but his scenes were filmed in time for the Thanksgiving holiday.
The filmmakers frequently fell behind schedule during the production of Blade Runner 2049.
During the production of Blade Runner 2049, an Origo Studios-employed subcontractor was killed by falling debris when dismantling one of the sets.
Blade Runner 2049 is the third Deakins-Villeneuve collaboration after Prisoners and Sicario (2015).
Together with production designer Dennis Gassner, Deakins and Villeneuve brainstormed ideas for the film's visual palette as Villeneuve was editing his science fiction drama Arrival (2016).

node_2: brutalist style for fictionalized los angeles
edge: Deakins and Villeneuve developed a hostile, imposing brutalist style for their fictionalized Los Angeles by being inspired by the architecture of several global cities.

node_1: brutalist style for fictionalized los angeles
edge: Deakins and Villeneuve drew inspiration from the appearance of Beijing's cityscape in dense smog, the foothills of southern Spain, Bangladeshi shipyards, and certain mid-twentieth-century landmarks in London (such as the Barbican Estate and Trellick Tower) to develop a brutalist style for their fictionalized Los Angeles.

node_2: intense dust storms in sahara, saudi arabia and sydney
edge: Deakins and Villeneuve researched intense dust storms in the Sahara, Saudi Arabia and Sydney to replicate the sandy desert ruins Villeneuve sought for Las Vegas-set scenes.
Deakins expressed that Blade Runner 2049 would be one of his biggest undertakings due to the technical demands involved in realizing its onscreen universe.
The extent of Deakins' oversight meant a single-camera setup for the set in Blade Runner 2049.
A studio line producer requested a nine unit-camera setup for Blade Runner 2049, but Deakins rejected it because he believed said technique would yield sloppy camerawork.
Deakins and Villeneuve reprised the practical approach of their previous collaborations to capture Blade Runner 2049 scenes.

node_2: single arri alexa xt studio camera
edge: Deakins and Villeneuve chose to shoot Blade Runner 2049 scenes using a single Arri Alexa XT Studio camera.
Deakins and Villeneuve preferred the somewhat grainy image quality of the Arri Alexa XT Studio camera in Blade Runner 2049.
Deakins and Villeneuve used 32 mm lenses to capture close-up character scenes in Blade Runner 2049, but used 14 mm and 16 mm lenses for sweeping cityscape shots.
Deakins and Villeneuve used Arri Alexa Mini cameras to represent views from the spinners in Blade Runner 2049.

When Gassner was first approached for Blade Runner 2049, he was called by Villeneuve to observe the shape of passing street sweepers. The designer had known Scott since 1982 and their collaboration started with Francis Ford Coppola-directed musical One From the Heart. Redesigning the spinners then became one of his initial responsibilities. The harsh, angular design for the spinners was intended to evoke the sense of technological innovation.

It was also up to Gassner to complete most of the Blade Runner 2049 sets so producers could exercise full artistic control of the shoot. Gassner described the process as especially difficult as design elements had to be distinct but lore-faithful, with everything executed under a tight shooting schedule.
In early October 2016, Warner Bros. Announced the title of the film.
Editing for the film commenced in December with the intention of having it be rated R.
At the 2017 San Diego Comic-Con, Villeneuve said the film would run for two hours and 32 minutes.
An early cut of the film was four hours long,
Villeneuve described this version as 'quite strong', but also at times 'too self-indulgent'.
He said he prefers the shorter final version, which is 'more elegant', though Ridley Scott has voiced the opinion that it is still too long.

node_2: most anticipated releases of the season
edge: According to a survey from Fandango, the film was indicated as one of the most anticipated releases of the season.
The film was initially projected to gross $43–47 million in its opening weekend in the United States and Canada.
The film's opening weekend was $31.5 million.
The film's opening weekend, performing below both projections but still finishing first at the box office, went on to debut and marked the biggest openings of Villeneuve and Gosling's careers.
The film's opening weekend record was overtaken by Barbie six years later.

Regarding the opening weekend, director Villeneuve said, "It's a mystery. All the indexes and marketing tools they were using predicted that it would be a success. The film was acclaimed by critics. So everyone expected the first weekend's results to be impressive, and they were shocked. They still don't understand."
The success of 'Blade Runner 2049' at the box office can be attributed to the direction of Villeneuve, who has gained critical acclaim for his work on the film.
The 163-minute runtime of 'Blade Runner 2049' has limited the number of showtimes in theaters, resulting in lower box office performance.
The lack of mainstream audience appeal for 'Blade Runner 2049' has contributed to its lower box office performance.
The marketing strategy for 'Blade Runner 2049' was vague and heavily relied on nostalgia and the established fanbase to carry it, which may have limited its appeal to mainstream audiences.
'Happy Death Day' outperformed 'Blade Runner 2049' at the box office in its second and third weekends, which may indicate a preference for certain genres or audiences.
'Boo 2! A Madea Halloween' outperformed 'Blade Runner 2049' at the box office in its third weekend, indicating a preference for certain genres or audiences.
